article_title: Willie Velásquez’s foresight still paying off
article_text:
Willie Velásquez’s foresight still paying off

Photo: Courtesy / Courtesy The late Willie Velasquez, founder and president of the Southwest...

Willie Velásquez always was ahead of the curve. In the 1970s and ’80s, the voting rights crusader saw way beyond the immediate implications of the great demographic wave the United States soon would experience.

article_metadata.description: Before the dramatic increases in the Latino population were apparent to local, state and federal officials, before corporate America got on board and before data about Latinos was pouring out of public policy institutes that soon would arise, Velásquez was thinking about next steps.  Leaders, veterans and longtime advocates of the two organizations he founded — the Southwest Voter Registration Education Project and the William C. Velásquez Institute — gathered last week in San Antonio to celebrate the latter’s 30th anniversary.  Turns out, the Republican hopeful has become a Latino voting rights advocate’s best ally.  Texas will hit a record 3 million registered Latino voters by the 2016 presidential election, and more than 2 million of them will cast ballots.  Gonzalez acknowledged that such gains were possible then because Congress was much more responsive to the Latino issues.  [...] the institute has been involved in climate change issues, reflecting not only a Latino grass-roots interest but the Latino leadership it will require.  The institute is also interested in the implications of marijuana legalization and in pushing for piecemeal work on immigration reform legislation, an idea wholly rejected by Democratic leadership.
article_metadata.author.name: By Elaine Ayala, Opinion Columnist

og.description: Before the dramatic increases in the Latino population were apparent to local, state and federal officials, before corporate America got on board and before data about Latinos was pouring out of public policy institutes that soon would arise, Velásquez was thinking about next steps.  Leaders, veterans and longtime advocates of the two organizations he founded — the Southwest Voter Registration Education Project and the William C. Velásquez Institute — gathered last week in San Antonio to celebrate the latter’s 30th anniversary.  Turns out, the Republican hopeful has become a Latino voting rights advocate’s best ally.  Texas will hit a record 3 million registered Latino voters by the 2016 presidential election, and more than 2 million of them will cast ballots.  Gonzalez acknowledged that such gains were possible then because Congress was much more responsive to the Latino issues.  [...] the institute has been involved in climate change issues, reflecting not only a Latino grass-roots interest but the Latino leadership it will require.  The institute is also interested in the implications of marijuana legalization and in pushing for piecemeal work on immigration reform legislation, an idea wholly rejected by Democratic leadership.
